titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Resting the principal part of the day from the fatigues of my voyage. Mr: Bourne dined with us, but left us early to go to the play. Bielfeld called here in the afternoon. Saw him with much pleasure. Walk with him in the wood. Whitcomb came with my baggage.
Ordinary day. The first after my return. Of course not yet fixed.

2. Devoted the forenoon to formal visits. First to the President of the National Assembly. Vos van Steenwyk; who is ex-officio President of the Commission for foreign affairs. Then to Mr: Van Leyden, Secretary of the same Committee. To Noël Minister from France, Baron de Schubart from Denmark, Chevalier d’Araujo from Portugal, Bielfeld who is not Chargé d’Affaires from Prussia, & Reuterswerd, who is from Sweden. Also to Mr: Levsen, Secretary of the Danish Legation. Saw only the three first and the last.— Wrote a few lines. In the Evening at the french Minister’s weekly tea and card party. Met several of my acquaintance there. Mr: Dumas, and his daughter Madam Veerman, which was quite unexpected to her. Not long there.

3. Visit this morning from Mr: Slicher, Agent of the National Assembly, who came by their order to compliment me upon my return, and to give assurances of their friendship for the United States. Wrote a letter or two. Walk; but a short one in the wood.— Party at the Went to hear the debates at the National Assembly. Particular Gallery allotted to diplomatics. Met Mr: Bosset there. He has just returned as well as myself.

4. All the forenoon writing to the Secretary of State. Walk with Bielfeld in the wood. Evening at the Play. German company. Very indifferent. King Theodore an Opera. Music of Paësiello. They made even that tiresome. A little weariness in spite of myself at the solitude here, compared with the bustle of London. But the life on the whole infinitely better suited to my taste.

5. Fine weather. Wrote part of a letter to my father. Long and pleasant walk with Bielfeld. Met Mr: Levsen and afterwards Mr: d’Araujo, who has just returned from the Country. Evening at Madam Veerman’s. Visit this afternoon from M. d’Araujo

6. Finished my letter of yesterday. Walk with Bielfeld in the wood. Dined with M: d’Araujo. Bielfeld, Levsen, a physician whose name I know not. Mr: Manoel a Portuguese gentleman of a singular character, and my brother were of the company. We talk’d something of literature a subject in which Mr: d’Araujo delights.— He says the Dauphin Editions of the classics are contemptible. The Dictys Cretensis only is in some estimation because it is the only handsome edition of that author that has ever been published.— Delille’s french translation of the Georgics is the only good french poetical translation extant. The eclogues by Gresset are very indifferent. The Italian translation of Virgil by Hannibal Caro is not equal to its reputation, nor equal to Dryden’s. He prefers even a Portuguese translation though in stanza’s. d’Araujo writes Portuguese verses himself and has recently translated Gray’s famous Elegy and Popes Messiah into that language. Mr: Manoël was compelled to fly from the fangs of the Inquisition for having translated Voltaire’s Pucelle d’Orleans. He is now translating Silius Italicus.— After dinner we compared the President Henault’s translation of the exordium of Lucretius, with the original; it has merit, but many weak lines. He shew us his Ariosto, Edition of Baskerville. the plates of Bartolozzi are very fine.— Walk with Bielfeld. When I came home I looked over Dryden’s translation of the first verses of Lucretius. Rather loosely done.—

7. It takes much of my time to recover the general information of the state of affairs which has been interrupted by my long absence. Wrote however something this day. Retrieved part of my arrears. Impertinent letter from the Contre-Amiral Van Stabel.— Evening saw Madam Dumas.

8. Called on the french Minister Noël: shew him the letters of Van Stabel and of Mr: Rohan. Told him I chose not to have any discussion with the former, being displeased with the style of his letter. He said it was certainly very improper, and that he had heard many complaints of his conduct.— Wrote Mr: Bourne. Papers from America.— Evening at Madam Veerman’s.— Attended the debates in the Assembly.

9. Letter from my brother Charles, and answered it. It kept great part of the day at home. Walk in the wood towards Evening.— At the french Minister’s weekly party. Company numerous.— Called in the morning upon Mr: Van Leyden, Secretary to the Committee for foreign affairs. Conversation with him on the new tonnage duty. Met him again in the evening.— He promises to attend as early as possible to my business.— Came away with Bielfeld; and walk with him on the Voorhout. Talk’d too much.

10. Letter to the Secretary of State; took me the greatest part of the day. Walk however in the wood. Met Messrs: Bielfeld and Levsen on my return. Short walk with them. Evening at M. de Schubart’s. Madam was very civil; but said she had almost a mind to quarrel with me for not calling to see her sooner. Not quite so zealous in her politics, as she was before I went away.

11. Visit in the morning from Mr: Levsen. Walk with him in the wood. Met Bielfeld who joined us. Met also Mr: W. Willink and had a little conversation with him relative to our money concerns. Find it necessary to enquire on this subject.— Gorani Memoirs of the Courts of Italy.— Begin to read and write as in former times. Evening at Mr: Veerman’s.
12. Visit from Bielfeld. long walk with him in the wood.— Writing to the Secretary of the Treasury. Reading as usual.— Walk in the Evening towards Delft and home early.

13. Attended the session of the National Assembly. Hahn President. Could understand very little of what was said. Walk afterwards alone in the wood. Reading in the afternoon. Evening at Madam Dumas’s. The old gentleman prejudiced according to custom. Cannot bear to think that the Americans import a great quantity of manufactures from England.— Puzzling my brain with some lines of Lucretius.

14. Writing most of the forenoon to the Secretary of State. Walk in the wood alone. Evening at the play. The Barbier de Seville in German with the music of Paësiello. The performance wretched but the music charming. Met Bielfeld, and one of the french Secretaries named Souque. An extreme coxcomb with great affectation of literary taste.

15. Earlier rising. A morning hour devoted to studious reading. Finished my letter to the Secretary of State.— Walk in the wood. Met Bielfeld and my brother. Bielfeld has a great deal of acquired understanding, but not a very brilliant natural genius. His feelings lead him to demonstrate sentiments but his judgment very often corrects their propensities.— Finished reading Pope’s translation of the Odyssey, in pursuit of the plan which I undertook in the midst of my English idleness and have hitherto persevered in since my return, though much less inclined to censure myself on that score at present. I have not yet become perfectly studious and busy according to my wishes, but I
I am gradually verging towards it, and if I did not know my weakness I should anticipate a better account of my customary day at the commencement of the ensuing month, than I have hitherto been able to give since I adopted this species of self admonition.— But wait and see. This afternoon a Mr: René Pillet called on me. Said he was formerly an Aid de Camp to M. de la Fayette, now a naturalized American citizen. Was going last week from England to Hamburg in the British Packet, and taken by a french frigate. Sent to Flushing. Plundered of his baggage. sent to Ghent and Antwerp. detained there as suspected, and at length ordered to depart within 48 hours. He had a bill of £200 sterling on Hamburg (a second) and finding himself short of money to proceed on his voyage wanted to have twenty pounds sterling discounted upon his bill. He had a Passport from Mr: Pinckney, and letters very recommendatory from Major Jackson and Mrs: Bingham. Sent to enquire of Messrs: Moliere whether they would discount the money. They refused but let him have 240 florins upon my order on the bankers at Amsterdam, which he engages to repay at Hamburg.— Perhaps an imprudence. But he has no appearance of being an impostor and is in a situation which requires assistance. He is further going to labour in behalf of M. de la Fayette, a cause which I would promote by all the means in my power.— Wrote by him an answer to the letter of Madame de la Fayette, which Mr: Lally delivered me in the winter. After part of the day, wholly thus employed.— Bed early.

16. Two hours of reading before breakfast.— Writing afterwards two or three hours. Walk alone in the wood. Reading again after dinner. Evening at the french Minister’s party. Met there Mr Van Leyden, who tells me that the affair of the double last-geld, is merely a question as to the Jurisdiction between the Committees of Marine and of the Colonies— Conversed with him concerning Mr: Rotch’s business. The application must be to the Committee of Marine, who exercise judicial powers. Conversation also with Mr: Lestevenon. Both these were some thing under the former Government. Their public characters do not sit upon them like new cloathes. They have neither the pretensions, nor the aukwardness observable in some others. Talk’d also with a man whose name I know not. He seems to regret the power of delay which he thinks the Government will lose by the change from federalism to Unity and Indivisibility. long explanation of what it was, which I very well knew before. Met there with Reuterswerd, the Swedish Consul at Rotterdam. Handsome, civil Gentleman. Rather proud of the three crowns on his buttons.— Mr: Levsen to whom I lent the other day two volumes of Le Beau. Histoire du Bas Empire. Thinks them ennuyans.— Very regular man— Says when he gets into a certain habitual mode of life, he cannot bear to have it deranged. (pace Dr: Johnson. for I like the word.) Home early.— My brother pass’d the Evening with Mr: Clagett.

div.p:
17. Letter and Packets this morning from Hall. rejoyced to receive them. Brought by a Mr Bainbridge, a young physician from New-York lately come from Edinburgh. He brought me
a letter of Introduction from Rogers, but went on immediately to Amsterdam. Wrote to Hall in answer and to Louisa.— Translating from the Dutch, for the Secretary of state. so very busy, scarce able to find time for my regular walk. Took it partly in the Evening. On returning received from Mr: Luzac two copies of his Oration de Socrate Cive with annotations. Addressed to my father. Kept my time for bed.

18. Three hours of reading before breakfast. Reading Smith’s Wealth of Nations; a work quite equal to its reputation. Answered Mr: Luzac’s letter. Received one from Mr Pillet.— Very busy again in the forenoon, but in writing, I cannot work with rapidity.— Short walk before dinner.— Evening at the German Play.— House uncommonly full. Don Juan, changed to an Opera. Music of Mosart, and very excellent. Performance indifferent as usual.

19. My labours grow upon me in proportion to my Industry. Bielfeld called on me. Mr: Bourne called to see me. Wrote one or two short letters. Walk in the wood alone. Afternoon in the customary form— Evening at Mr: Veerman’s. found some company there. Short walk afterwards and early home.

20. After my morning’s reading, and my hour of translation from the Dutch, before I had begun upon my letter writing Bielfeld called on me. took a long walk with him, but so much engaged in Conversation that I took scarce any notice of it at all.— Mr: Bourne dined with us. Afternoon of course partly devoted to relaxation. Made out however to read a Book of the Eneid of Dryden.

21. Letter from the Secretary of State. Began an answer to it. Wrote to Mr: Pinckney. To the Bankers at Amsterdam, enclosing the bills of Exchange. Mr: Houghton and Mr: Snowdon here in the morning. Mr: Clagett in the afternoon. He went on with his companions Bainbridge and Barksdale, to Rotterdam. Mr: Melvill towards night, with a letter of Introduction from Mr: Beeldemaker. What with the visitors, the letters and the hurry of writing made quite a busy day.

22. More quiet day than several of the past. Finished my letter to the Secretary of State— Rainy, and therefore could not walk before dinner.— Evening at Mr: Veerman’s. Madam Dumas, who went away. Conversation with Madame Veerman. She goes into the Country for the Summer to-morrow. Quite dissatisfied with myself.

23. Another very quiet and studious day. Began a letter to my father. Walk in the wood before dinner. Received the two bills of Exchange again from Messrs: Willink, with a request to endorse them to the two houses. Did so accordingly for the account of the Department of State, and carried them, at the beginning of the Evening to Mr: N. Van Staphorst. My brother attended the french minister’s tea party. I took a walk towards Delft, and returned shortly before ten.

24. Up this morning at half past four. Rather too early, and of course weary through the day. Walk in the wood met Messrs: Bielfeld and Levsen. My brother went in the afternoon to the fair, at Delft.— Usual reading and writing. Evening walk in the Voorhout. Met again both the gentlemen before mentioned, and also Mr: Reuterswerd. First warm & pleasant weather.

25. Not quite so early this morning. Employ my whole time very busily; but fear too many objects are embraced at once. Eyes failing.— Walk in the wood, alone. At the play. Carl von Eichenhorst an Opera, from a Poem of Bürger. Music good but much of it pilfered. Walk with Bielfeld after the play. Met Mr: Levsen. Home half after ten. Weather fine.

26. Walk in the wood. Met Messrs: Bielfeld and Levsen. Weather uncomfortably warm. Evening from half past six till half past twelve at Reuterswerd’s: playing quadrill the whole time. Found it excessively tedious. Mr: and Madame Cneiff. Mr: Euler, Mr: Bosset, and Bielfeld were of the company. Mr: d’Araujo was there about half an hour and went away. Doctor Huymans. We came home in a light thunder shower.

27. Lost none of my time this morning, from being late out yesterday. Walk in the wood. Finished Gorani’s memoirs of the Courts of Italy. a very superficial work, and a very conceited author. I expected to have derived much more information from him than I have been able to obtain. I was pleased however with what he says of my old friend Count Greco, and think it very just.— Finished also Dryden’s translation of the Eneid. The verse is more harmonious than I expected; and the fourth book in particular is laboured con amore. But the triplets and Alexandrines are too frequent, the verse is sometimes surprizingly careless, and the expressions too often technical or vulgar. The preface is what the french call a mauvaise plaisanterie. A pretended defence, of what is indefensible the morality of the Poem, and its Hero.— Walk again in the Evening.

28. Finished this morning, Smith’s Wealth of Nations, a book which I have long been determined to read without ever executing the intention before. I must read it again with great attention, as it is a book not only to be read, but studied and meditated. In addition to all my other employments I have now undertaken to learn a little Italian. Took a lesson this morning in company with Bielfeld.— Mr: Moliere called on me having received Mr: Pillet’s note returned from Hamburg. His correspondent says Mr: Pillet was not to be found at the place indicated. Told him I supposed he had not then arrived there, and requested him to send the note again, which he agreed to do. Short walk with Bielfeld, but it rained. Weather very chilly.— Extremely drowsy and dull this afternoon. Evening walk somewhat refreshed me. Begun in the afternoon upon Pitt’s translation of the Eneid, and the life of Dumouriez.

29. Commenced this morning a work entitled Richesse de la Hollande by Elias Luzac; a work which I once before attempted to read, but could not effect it. Tis more tedious than Coke-Littleton or Hawkins’s Pleas of the Crown. But as it contains much information relative to the commerce of this Country, I must overcome the aversion and disgust it gives and swallow it like a dose of rhubarb.— Finished a letter to the Secy: of State— Wrote somewhat else. Walk in the wood and met Mr: Levsen. Walk again alone round the town in the Evening.

30. Afflicted with an inflammation in one of my eyes. it has not yet however made me relax from my adopted system. Wrote not much this day. Made out my account for the Department of State. Short walk before dinner. Met Messrs: Bielfeld and Levsen. Evening at the french Minister’s weekly party. This is to be the last for the season. They are to begin again in October. Company not very numerous. Met Mr: Schimmelpenninck there. He told me the Constitutional Committee had some wish to introduce the trial by jury, into their new system, and enquired of me what book contained any account of that Institution. Told him I knew of none better than that contained in Blackstone’s Commentaries.— Considerable conversation with him on this subject, and some others. He appears to have sober and rational ideas relative to Government, but many of his colleagues are far from thinking like him.

Day. On my return from England I determined to resume a life of application to business and study, which during the principal part of my residence there I found altogether impossible. It has not yet settled into a course perfectly regular, but it is hitherto equal to my expectations. Rise and dress at six. Read works of instruction, from thence till nine. Breakfast. read the papers and translate from the Dutch till eleven or twelve. Then dress for the day. Write letters or attend to other business that occurs till between two and three. Walk till half past three. Dine and sit till five. Read works of amusement till between eight & nine. Walk again about an hour. then take a very slight supper, and my segar, and retire to bed at eleven.— The variations from this course are not considerable. those that have taken place as yet are marked in the diary. I have as before mentioned now devoted an hour a day to the study of Italian, which Bielfeld and I are learning together.— Too much of this time is devoted to reading, and too little to Society. But I was not formed to shine in company, nor to be delighted with it; and I have now a considerable lapse of time to repair. While in London, by far too large a portion of my time was spent it.— I hope and intend at a future time to take some of my present reading hours, for the purpose of writing. I wish no other change.

In my morning reading I have gone through Smith’s Wealth of Nations, and commenced Luzac’s Richesse de la Hollande. I have never had the advantage of systematic reading in its perfection, because I was never taught a system. To form one for myself has been the subject of my frequent meditations, but I have never satisfied myself as to the detail. My studies are indeed all directed to one point, which is pointed out to me by the station that I hold. The ultimate object of all reading must be the improvement of the mind— But how to compass the greatest quantum of improvement, in a given portion of time and study is a problem, that I have not yet solved, and of which I still seek the solution.— My afternoon reading has been, one hour of epic verse in English, which has carried me through Pope’s Homer & Dryden’s Eneid. I have now begun upon that of Pitt.— The Memoires Secrets at Critiques des Cours d’ltalie of Gorani, I read in consequence of their reputation, and because I wanted information relative to the present state of that Country. They have accordingly furnished me with new materials for knowledge, but the book is superficial, and dull; full of common place political folly and personal scandal. Such books cost only the trouble of writing them. The author thinks himself a profound legislator, while he is only a coxcomb and a pedant. The life of Dumouriez, is of quite a different description. The book is as entertaining as the principles of the author are depraved.— I mean to speak of him again.
